text: <https://berthub.eu/articles/posts/reverse-engineering-source-code-of-the-biontech-pfizer-vaccine/>

attachments.title: Reverse Engineering the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine - Articles
attachments.text: Welcome! In this post, we’ll be taking a character-by-character look at the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine. I want to thank the large cast of people who spent time previewing this article for legibility and correctness. All mistakes remain mine though, but I would love to hear about them quickly at <mailto:bert@hubertnet.nl|bert@hubertnet.nl> or @PowerDNS_Bert Now, these words may be somewhat jarring - the vaccine is a liquid that gets injected in your arm.
attachments.fallback: Articles: Reverse Engineering the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine - Articles

text: Alas, the compiler is written by evolution, and therefore largely inscrutable.

elements.text: Alas, the compiler is written by evolution, and therefore largely inscrutable.

text: compiler updates are the end goal anyway, right?

elements.text: compiler updates are the end goal anyway, right?

text:
It's probably a terrible analogy, and I don't think I know enough computer science to take me much further. TBH, I don't totally understand what compilers do :smile:

I know a lot of molecular biology and evolution though...

elements.text: It's probably a terrible analogy, and I don't think I know enough computer science to take me much further. TBH, I don't totally understand what compilers do
I know a lot of molecular biology and evolution though...

text: I’m not reading that full article, but is there enough code so that if you had a suitable printer, you could make the vaccine yourself?

elements.text: I’m not reading that full article, but is there enough code so that if you had a suitable printer, you could make the vaccine yourself?

text: no

elements.text: no

text: the process is vastly more complicated than that

elements.text: the process is vastly more complicated than that

text: in terms of programming, you have the source code and a rough map how it works, but no clue about the build chain from that article

elements.text: in terms of programming, you have the source code and a rough map how it works, but no clue about the build chain from that article

text: Yeah, it's not just the sequence, but also packaging. Injecting straight mRNA, you might have a local inflammatory response, but the molecule would just get degraded. It would not go into cells and would not make any protein, which is what the immune system needs to see to actually make a functional response

elements.text: Yeah, it's not just the sequence, but also packaging. Injecting straight mRNA, you might have a local inflammatory response, but the molecule would just get degraded. It would not go into cells and would not make any protein, which is what the immune system needs to see to actually make a functional response

text: the way I've come to think of it is that DNA is source-codeish, proteins that synthesize proteins from DNA are compilerish and proteins in general are messages/programs/data/events, all at once

elements.text: the way I've come to think of it is that DNA is source-codeish, proteins that synthesize proteins from DNA are compilerish and proteins in general are messages/programs/data/events, all at once

text: so "compiler update" would really be customizing the protein synthesis process further than putting in different source code

elements.text: so "compiler update" would really be customizing the protein synthesis process further than putting in different source code

text: So this vaccine is like a source-injection exploit, and the published sequence there is just the malware itself, and doesn't contain the info about how to actually get it on the system?

elements.text: So this vaccine is like a source-injection exploit, and the published sequence there is just the malware itself, and doesn't contain the info about how to actually get it on the system?

text: more a blueprint for the "malware", but essentially, yes

elements.text: more a blueprint for the "malware", but essentially, yes

text: as I understand it, it's not even the full malware, but only what is needed such that the anti-virus (our immune system) recognizes  and learns to detect it

elements.text: as I understand it, it's not even the full malware, but only what is needed such that the anti-virus (our immune system) recognizes  and learns to detect it

text: The biology pedant in me is really shuddering here, but it's not all that bad as a metaphor :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: The biology pedant in me is really shuddering here, but it's not all that bad as a metaphor

text: Oh, if the virus itself is the malware, yeah

elements.text: Oh, if the virus itself is the malware, yeah

text: in terms of when this virus hit, we're really lucky - a few years earlier and we might not even have had the tools to know what to synthesize in the first place

elements.text: in terms of when this virus hit, we're really lucky - a few years earlier and we might not even have had the tools to know what to synthesize in the first place

text: Yep, I keep telling people that as bad as this pandemic is, (a) we're super fortunate we saw SARS1 and MERS first, then funded basic research on them, (b) we're pretty advanced in our technology so we had a good shot at dealing with it, and (c) we got hit with something that was bad enough to kick us into gear, so that we'll have a jump start on the next one.

elements.text: Yep, I keep telling people that as bad as this pandemic is, (a) we're super fortunate we saw SARS1 and MERS first, then funded basic research on them, (b) we're pretty advanced in our technology so we had a good shot at dealing with it, and (c) we got hit with something that was bad enough to kick us into gear, so that we'll have a jump start on the next one.

text: My worry is if the next one doesn't have the base we've had here

elements.text: My worry is if the next one doesn't have the base we've had here

text: but that's no reason not to go outside and eat all the tasty things, of course :p

elements.text: but that's no reason not to go outside and eat all the tasty things, of course :p

text: A lot of mistakes were also made in the years before this pandemic. You know better what The U.S. did, but in Finland they scaled down personnel who were experts in infectious diseases some years earlier. Also we had a lot of PPE in storage, but they were all expired I believe. Sweden had scaled down those kinds of storage years earlier. The storage I mean were originally made in preparation for possible war decades earlier.
